case_name: State of West Bengal v. K. Mondal Sons

facts.text: Suit filed by respondent K. Mondal Sons against appellant State of West Bengal claiming Rs. 19,325/- for works done.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises out of a suit filed by the respondent K. Mondal Sons against the appellant the State of West Bengal on the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court claiming a sum of Rs. 19,325/- for works done by it for the appellant.

facts.text: On February 8, 1944, respondent offered to put up temporary storage godowns at Arambagh for Civil Supplies Department.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents case was that on February 8, 1944, it offered to put up certain temporary storage godowns at Arambagh in the District of Hooghly for the use of the Civil Supplies Department of the State of Bengal

facts.text: Offer accepted by letter dated February 12, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: and that the said offer was accepted by the said department by a letter dated February 12, 1944.

facts.text: Godowns completed and bill for Rs. 39,476/- paid in July 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly the respondent companypleted the said companystruction and its bill for Rs. 39,476/- was duly paid in July 1944.

facts.text: On April 7, 1944, Sub-Divisional Officer, Arambagh requested estimate for construction of kutcha road, guard room, office, kitchen and room for clerks.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, on April 7, 1944, the respondent was requested by the Sub-Divisional Officer, Arambagh, to submit its estimate for the companystruction of a kutcha road, guard room, office, kitchen and room for clerks at Arambagh

facts.text: Additional Deputy Director of Civil Supplies visited Arambagh on April 20, 1944, and instructed respondent to proceed with construction.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent alleged that the Additional Deputy Director of Civil Supplies visited Arambagh on April 20, 1944, and instructed the respondent to proceed with the companystruction in accordance with the estimates submitted by it.

facts.text: Constructions completed and bill for Rs. 2,322/8 submitted to Assistant Director on April 27, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly the respondent companypleted the said companystructions and a bill for Rs. 2,322/8 was submitted in that behalf to the Assistant Director of Civil Supplies on April 27, 1944.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Officer required construction of storage sheds at Khanakul; Assistant Director wrote on April 18, 1944 to proceed.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Sub-Divisional Officer, Arambagh required the companystruction of certain storage sheds at Khanakul and the Assistant Director of Civil Supplies wrote to the respondent on April 18, 1944, asking it to proceed with the companystruction of the said storage sheds.

facts.text: Work completed, bill for Rs. 17,003/- submitted.

anchor.surface_text: This work also was companypleted by the respondent in due companyrse and for the said work a bill for Rs. 17,003/- was submitted.

facts.text: Appellant denied all material allegations and claimed no valid contract under s.175(3) of Government of India Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant denied all the material allegations made by the respondent in its plaint. It alleged that the requests in pursuance of which the respondent claims to have made the several companystructions were invalid and unauthorised

facts.text: Trial judge G.K. Mitter J. held no valid contract under s.175(3), but claim justified under s.70 Contract Act, not barred by limitation, liability devolved.

anchor.surface_text: However, G.K. Mitter, J., who tried the suit, framed five material issues on the pleadings and recorded his findings on them. He held that having regard to the provisions of s. 175 3  of the Act there was numbervalid and binding companytract between the respondent and the appellant

facts.text: Decree passed in favour of respondent for amount claimed.

anchor.surface_text: The result was that the respondents claim was upheld under s. 70 of the Contract Act and a decree for the amount claimed by it was accordingly passed in its favour.

facts.text: Appeal to Calcutta High Court, Civil Appeal From Original Decree No. 155 of 1953, heard by S.R. Das Gupta and Bachawat JJ., dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 286 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated the January 4, 1957, of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Appeal From Original Decree No. 155 of 1953.

facts.text: Contracts not executed by persons authorised by Governor as per s.175(3), common ground.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon-ground that the companytracts in question were number executed by any persons duly authorised by the Governor in that behalf,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds contracts invalid due to non-compliance with s.175(3).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there can be numberdoubt that failure to companyply with the mandatory provisions of the said section makes the companytracts invalid.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds s.70 of Contract Act applies, appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The result is the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Suit filed in 1949 against Province of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: As the respondent did number receive payment for the work, it filed a suit in the Original Side of the High Court at Calcutta in 1949 against the Province of West Bengal

facts.text: Officers had no authority to bind government, known to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: These officers, however, had number been authorised by the Government to make the request on its behalf and the respondent was aware of such lack of authority all along.

facts.text: Government enjoyed benefit of the works.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that Government had taken the benefit of the work.

facts.text: Liability devolved on State of West Bengal under Indian Independence (Rights, Property and Liabilities) Order 1947.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of s. 175(3) of the Government of India Act, 1935 are mandatory/obligatory or merely directory

anchor.surface_text: The question as to whether mandatory provisions contained in statutes should be considered merely as directory or obligatory has often been considered in judicial decisions. In dealing with the question no general or inflexible rule can be laid down.

holdings.text: Failure to comply with the mandatory provisions of s.175(3) of the Government of India Act, 1935 makes the contracts invalid.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there can be nodoubt that failure to comply with the mandatory provisions of the said section makes the contracts invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.175(3) uses imperative 'shall'; legislative intent to protect state from unauthorised contracts; follows Bhikraj Jaipuria precedent.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.175(3) of the Government of India Act, 1935 are mandatory and obligatory, not directory.

anchor.surface_text: The question as to whether mandatory provisions contained in statutes should be considered merely as directory or obligatory has often been considered in judicial decisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Determined by legislative intent from scope, object; protects public interest against spurious claims.

holdings.text: s.70 of the Indian Contract Act applies to the facts of the case despite invalid contracts under s.175(3).

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that three conditions must be satisfied before this section can be invoked. The first condition is that a person should lawfully do something for another person

holdings.reasoning_summary: Three conditions satisfied: work lawfully done non-gratuitously; government enjoyed benefit; independent of contract as quasi-contractual liability.

holdings.text: The respondent's claim is justified under s.70 of the Indian Contract Act.
